title: The most important century in human history

multiple-choice.question: What is considered the most important century in human history?

options.label: A
options.text: The 7th century, which saw the emergence of Islam.

options.label: B
options.text: The 300s BCE, which saw Alexander the Great's military campaigns.

options.label: C
options.text: The 1700s, which saw the Industrial Revolution.

options.label: D
options.text: The 21st century, which has seen rapid technological growth.

multiple-choice.question: What is the name of the technology that could introduce more existential risks this century?

options.label: A
options.text: Artificial General Intelligence (AGI)

options.label: B
options.text: Artificial Narrow Intelligence (ANI)

options.label: C
options.text: Machine Learning (ML)

options.label: D
options.text: Deep Learning (DL)

multiple-choice.question: What is the estimated risk of existential catastrophe due to nuclear winter and climate change?
What is the estimated risk of a pandemic causing an existential collapse?
What is the difference between narrow AI and artificial general intelligence?

options.label: A
options.text: Narrow AI is designed to do specific tasks, while AGI can adapt to and perform any number of tasks.

options.label: B
options.text: Narrow AI is designed to perform any number of tasks, while AGI is limited to specific tasks.

options.label: C
options.text: Narrow AI is more powerful than AGI.

options.label: D
options.text: AGI is more powerful than narrow AI.

multiple-choice.question: What is the potential outcome of an AGI emerging with deep respect for human life?

options.label: A
options.text: It would lead to a utopian society.

options.label: B
options.text: It would become misaligned and pose an existential risk.

options.label: C
options.text: It would become hegemonic and lock humanity into one ideology.

options.label: D
options.text: It would become obsolete.

multiple-choice.question: What is the challenge of developing AGI that aligns with human values?

options.label: A
options.text: It is an easy task.

options.label: B
options.text: It is a difficult philosophical and engineering challenge.

options.label: C
options.text: It is not a challenge at all.

options.label: D
options.text: It is a challenge that has already been solved.

multiple-choice.question: What is the potential impact of AGI on humanity's moral growth?

options.label: A
options.text: It would lead to a permanent increase in moral growth.

options.label: B
options.text: It would lead to a permanent decrease in moral growth.

options.label: C
options.text: It would lead to a permanent distortion or constraint of moral growth.

options.label: D
options.text: It would have no impact on moral growth.

multiple-choice.question: What is the uncertainty surrounding AGI?

options.label: A
options.text: There is no uncertainty at all.

options.label: B
options.text: There is some uncertainty, but it is manageable.

options.label: C
options.text: There is a lot of uncertainty, and it's difficult to predict the outcome.

options.label: D
options.text: It's impossible to predict the outcome.

multiple-choice.question: What is the possible outcome of new, more pressing concerns rendering existential risks moot?

options.label: A
options.text: It would lead to a permanent increase in existential risks.

options.label: B
options.text: It would lead to a permanent decrease in existential risks.

options.label: C
options.text: It would lead to a permanent distortion or constraint of moral growth.

options.label: D
options.text: It would make it impossible to predict the outcome.

title: When you're an ant but also a fungus tycoon - Charles Wallace

options.label: B
options.text: The fungus is a crop that provides the ant with essential nutrients.

options.label: C
options.text: The ant is a parasite that feeds on the fungus's body.

options.label: D
options.text: The fungus is a weed that the ant tries to eradicate.

options.label: C

options.label: D

options.label: C

options.label: C
options.text: To forage for food and bring it back to the nest.

options.label: D

options.label: C

title: The man who lost his sense of touch - Antonio Cataldo

multiple-choice.question: What is deafferentation?

options.label: A
options.text: A condition in which certain signals from the nervous system are interrupted or impaired.

options.label: B
options.text: A condition in which the body's constant feedback on how its limbs are moving is disrupted.

options.label: C
options.text: A condition in which the body's senses are enhanced.

options.label: D
options.text: A condition in which the body's senses are reduced.

multiple-choice.question: What is the somatosensory system?

options.label: A
options.text: A network that oversees all the sensations arising from the surface and interior of our bodies.

options.label: B
options.text: A network that oversees all the sensations arising from the surface of our bodies.

options.label: C
options.text: A network that oversees all the sensations arising from the interior of our bodies.

options.label: D
options.text: A network that oversees all the sensations arising from the environment.

multiple-choice.question: What is the role of mechanoreceptors in the somatosensory system?

options.label: A
options.text: To sense temperature changes.

options.label: B
options.text: To sense pain.

options.label: C
options.text: To sense mechanical deformation of the skin.

options.label: D
options.text: To sense proprioception.

multiple-choice.question: What is the difference between nociceptors with thick and thin fibers?

options.label: A
options.text: Thick fibers are responsible for dull pain, while thin fibers are responsible for sharp pain.

options.label: B
options.text: Thick fibers are responsible for sharp pain, while thin fibers are responsible for dull pain.

options.label: C
options.text: Thick fibers are responsible for temperature changes, while thin fibers are responsible for pain.

options.label: D
options.text: Thick fibers are responsible for proprioception, while thin fibers are responsible for tactile sensations.

multiple-choice.question: What is the impact of damage to the somatosensory system?

options.label: A
options.text: It can manifest in a wide variety of ways, including the loss of tactile sensations and the inability to gauge how much strength to use in a situation.

options.label: B
options.text: It can only manifest in a few specific ways, such as the loss of tactile sensations.

options.label: C
options.text: It can only manifest in a few specific ways, such as the inability to gauge how much strength to use in a situation.

options.label: D
options.text: It has no impact on the body.

multiple-choice.question: What is touch starvation?

options.label: A
options.text: A condition characterized by anxiety, depression, high blood pressure, and a weakened immune system.

options.label: B
options.text: A condition characterized by low blood pressure, low anxiety, and a strong immune system.

options.label: C
options.text: A condition characterized by a lack of tactile sensations.

options.label: D
options.text: A condition characterized by a lack of proprioception.

multiple-choice.question: What is the role of the brain in the somatosensory system?

options.label: A
options.text: To combine information from the senses to move through space without needing to see the limbs.

options.label: B
options.text: To process information from the senses.

options.label: C
options.text: To ignore information from the senses.

options.label: D
options.text: To generate a constant flood of signals that travel through the nervous system.

multiple-choice.question: What is the impact of deafferentation?

options.label: A
options.text: It can leave a person unable to sit up, stand, or walk.

options.label: B
options.text: It can leave a person unable to gauge how much strength to use in a situation.

options.label: C
options.text: It can leave a person unable to react when their body is damaged.

options.label: D
options.text: All of the above.

multiple-choice.question: What is the difference between mechanoreceptors and nociceptors?

options.label: A
options.text: Mechanoreceptors sense mechanical deformation of the skin, while nociceptors sense pain.

options.label: B
options.text: Mechanoreceptors sense pain, while nociceptors sense mechanical deformation of the skin.

options.label: C
options.text: Mechanoreceptors sense temperature changes, while nociceptors sense pain.

options.label: D
options.text: Mechanoreceptors sense proprioception, while nociceptors sense tactile sensations.

multiple-choice.question: What is the role of the somatosensory system in navigation?

options.label: A
options.text: It helps us navigate through space without needing to see our limbs.

options.label: B
options.text: It helps us navigate through space by combining information from the senses.

options.label: C
options.text: It has no role in navigation.

options.label: D
options.text: It helps us navigate through space by ignoring information from the senses.

title: How do airplanes actually fly? - Raymond Adkins

multiple-choice.question: What is the relationship between space and time, as explained by Albert Einstein by 1917?

options.label: A
options.text: The relationship between space and time is not related to flight.

options.label: B
options.text: The relationship between space and time is a flawed theory of flight.

options.label: C
options.text: The relationship between space and time is an incomplete theory of flight.

options.label: D
options.text: The relationship between space and time is a fundamental concept in physics.

multiple-choice.question: What is the primary force called that an airplane needs to stay aloft, if it is heavier than air?

options.label: A
options.text: Thrust

options.label: B
options.text: Lift

options.label: C
options.text: Drag

options.label: D
options.text: Weight

multiple-choice.question: What is the "Longer Path" or "Equal Transit Time" explanation of lift?

options.label: A
options.text: A correct explanation of how lift is generated.

options.label: B
options.text: A flawed explanation of how lift is generated.

options.label: C
options.text: A simplified description of lift.

options.label: D
options.text: A mathematical formula for lift.

multiple-choice.question: What happens to the air molecules above and below the wing, as the wing moves forward?

options.label: A
options.text: They meet back up at the wing's trailing edge.

options.label: B
options.text: They split into pathways above and below the wing, following the wing's contour.

options.label: C
options.text: They are deflected downwards, creating a pressure difference.

options.label: D
options.text: They are swept up, then down, beyond the wing's surface.

multiple-choice.question: What is the result of the increased speed of the air above the wing, coupled with a decrease in pressure?

options.label: A
options.text: A decrease in lift.

options.label: B
options.text: An increase in drag.

options.label: C
options.text: An increase in pressure difference, resulting in the upwards force of lift.

options.label: D
options.text: A loss of stability.

multiple-choice.question: What happens to the airflow above a wing that is too curved or steeply angled?

options.label: A
options.text: It becomes turbulent and detached from the wing.

options.label: B
options.text: It becomes stable and attached to the wing.

options.label: C
options.text: It becomes slower and creates a higher pressure difference.

options.label: D
options.text: It becomes faster and creates a lower pressure difference.

multiple-choice.question: What is the set of formulas used by engineers to precisely model air's flow around a wing and detail how lift is generated?

options.label: A
options.text: The Bernoulli's principle.

options.label: B
options.text: The Navier-Stokes equations.

options.label: C
options.text: The Euler's equation.

options.label: D
options.text: The Newton's law.

title: History vs. Thomas Jefferson - Frank Cogliano

multiple-choice.question: Who was Thomas Jefferson?

options.label: A
options.text: A founding father of the United States of America and primary author of the Declaration of Independence.

options.label: B
options.text: A president who served during the Civil War.

options.label: C
options.text: A diplomat who negotiated the Treaty of Paris.

options.label: D
options.text: A Native American leader who fought in the Revolutionary War.

multiple-choice.question: What was the purpose of the Declaration of Independence?

options.label: A
options.text: To establish the US as a democratic republic on the principle that everyone is created equal.

options.label: B
options.text: To declare war on Great Britain.

options.label: C
options.text: To limit the power of the federal government.

options.label: D
options.text: To abolish slavery.

multiple-choice.question: What was one of the major issues with Thomas Jefferson's views on equality?

options.label: A
options.text: He believed that only white men should have the right to vote.

options.label: B
options.text: He believed that women should have equal rights.

options.label: C
options.text: He believed that enslaved people were intellectual inferiors.

options.label: D
options.text: He believed that Native Americans should have the right to self-governance.

multiple-choice.question: What was the Indian Removal Act, and what was its connection to Thomas Jefferson?

options.label: A
options.text: The Indian Removal Act was a law that forced Native Americans to relocate from their ancestral lands to Indian Territory.

options.label: B
options.text: The Indian Removal Act was a law that allowed Native Americans to purchase land from the federal government.

options.label: C
options.text: The Indian Removal Act was a law that was based on Thomas Jefferson's recommendations.

options.label: D
options.text: The Indian Removal Act was a law that was opposed by Thomas Jefferson.

multiple-choice.question: What was the significance of the Louisiana Purchase?

options.label: A
options.text: It marked the beginning of the US's westward expansion.

options.label: B
options.text: It marked the end of the US's involvement in the Napoleonic Wars.

options.label: C
options.text: It marked the beginning of the US's involvement in the Barbary Wars.

options.label: D
options.text: It had no significant impact on US history.

multiple-choice.question: What was the relationship between Thomas Jefferson and Sally Hemings?

options.label: A
options.text: They were married for many years.

options.label: B
options.text: They had a romantic relationship and had six children together.

options.label: C
options.text: They were distant relatives.

options.label: D
options.text: They were business partners.

multiple-choice.question: How many people did Thomas Jefferson free during his lifetime?
What was the significance of the law that Thomas Jefferson signed forbidding the importation of enslaved people in 1807?

options.label: A
options.text: It marked the end of slavery in the US.

options.label: B
options.text: It marked the beginning of the US's gradual abolition of slavery.

options.label: C
options.text: It had no significant impact on the institution of slavery.

options.label: D
options.text: It was repealed shortly after it was passed.

multiple-choice.question: What was the role of Thomas Jefferson in the US government?

options.label: A
options.text: He was a president who served for two terms.

options.label: B
options.text: He was a vice president who served under John Adams.

options.label: C
options.text: He was a diplomat who negotiated several treaties.

options.label: D
options.text: He was a senator who served for many years.

multiple-choice.question: What was the main argument of the History vs. Thomas Jefferson episode?

options.label: A
options.text: That Thomas Jefferson was a great leader who should be remembered for his accomplishments.

options.label: B
options.text: That Thomas Jefferson was a flawed individual who should be judged by modern standards.

options.label: C
options.text: That Thomas Jefferson was a typical product of his time who should not be held to modern standards.

options.label: D
options.text: That Thomas Jefferson was a villain who should be condemned for his actions.

title: What sex ed doesn’t tell you about your brain - Shannon Odell

title: You don't actually know what your future self wants - Shankar Vendantam

multiple-choice.question: What is the "illusion of continuity" that Shankar talks about in the podcast?

options.label: A
options.text: The idea that our future selves will be exactly the same as our current selves.

options.label: B
options.text: The idea that we will never change or grow as individuals.

options.label: C
options.text: The idea that we will always be able to imagine our future selves accurately.

options.label: D
options.text: The idea that we will always be able to predict our future desires and preferences.

multiple-choice.question: What is the "ship of Theseus" thought experiment that Shankar mentions?

options.label: A
options.text: A thought experiment about a ship that is repaired and replaced over time.

options.label: B
options.text: A thought experiment about a person who is replaced by a clone.

options.label: C
options.text: A thought experiment about a society that is rebuilt from scratch.

options.label: D
options.text: A thought experiment about a person who is frozen in time and thawed out in the future.

multiple-choice.question: What is Shankar's main argument about the illusion of continuity?

options.label: A
options.text: That we should try to be more like our future selves.

options.label: B
options.text: That we should try to change ourselves to fit our future selves.

options.label: C
options.text: That we should accept that our future selves will be different from our current selves.

options.label: D
options.text: That we should try to ignore the fact that our future selves will be different from our current selves.

options.label: C

options.label: D

options.label: B

options.label: C
options.text: To try to predict our future desires and preferences.

options.label: D

options.label: A
options.text: To try to be more confident and assertive.

options.label: B
options.text: To practice humility and acknowledge that we may be wrong.

options.label: C
options.text: To try to be more like our future selves.

options.label: D
options.text: To ignore the fact that our future selves will be different from our current selves.

options.label: A
options.text: To try to be more cautious and risk-averse.

options.label: B
options.text: To be brave and take risks.

options.label: C
options.text: To try to predict our future desires and preferences.

options.label: D
options.text: To ignore the fact that our future selves will be different from our current selves.

options.label: A
options.text: That we should try to be more like our future selves.

options.label: B
options.text: That we should try to change ourselves to fit our future selves.

title: The original ring of power - Alex Gendler

options.label: B
options.text: It is a Chinese philosophical legend.

options.label: C
options.text: It is a Greek philosophical story that appeared more than 2,000 years ago.

options.text: Socrates

options.label: B

options.label: C
options.text: Gyges

options.label: D
options.text: The king of Lydia

options.label: A
options.text: To illustrate the benefits of acting justly.

options.label: B
options.text: To demonstrate the consequences of acting unjustly.

options.label: C
options.text: To explore the nature of the human soul.

options.label: D
options.text: To discuss the role of authority in enforcing justice.

options.label: A
options.text: The first class, which we desire for their own sake.

options.label: B
options.text: The second class, which we want only for the value they bring.

options.label: C
options.text: The third class, which we desire for their own sake and the value they offer.

options.label: D
options.text: There is no clear classification.

options.label: A
options.text: Reason, spirit, and appetite.

options.label: B
options.text: Reason, spirit, and knowledge.

options.label: C
options.text: Reason, appetite, and ignorance.

options.label: D
options.text: Spirit, appetite, and ignorance.

multiple-choice.question: What is the implication of Socrates' view on the human soul regarding the tyrant and the philosopher?

options.label: A
options.text: The tyrant is guided by reason and the philosopher is driven by appetite.

options.label: B
options.text: The tyrant is enslaved to his own base desires and the philosopher is led by reason.

options.label: C
options.text: The tyrant is happy and the philosopher is unhappy.

options.label: D
options.text: The tyrant is unhappy and the philosopher is happy.
